jot.gui.camera

Class Camera

  • java.lang.Object
    • jot.gui.camera.Camera
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    FirstPerson, Perspective, PerspectiveFollow, PerspectiveRayTracer, ThirdPerson, UpperView, UpperViewFollow

    public abstract class Camera
extends Object
    Abstract class that implements a camera.
    Author:
    G. Amador & A. Gomes

    • Method Detail

      • getOrthographic

        public boolean getOrthographic()
        Get whether the current projection is orthographic or perspective. The default is perspective.
        Returns:
        TRUE if current projection is orthographic, FALSE if current projection is perspective.

      • setOrthographic

        public void setOrthographic(boolean orthographic)
        Determine whether the projection is orthographic or perspective. The default is perspective.
        Parameters:
        orthographic - set to true for orthographic projection and to false for perspective projection.

      • getPreserveAspect

        public boolean getPreserveAspect()
        Get whether the xy-limits should be adjusted to match the aspect ratio of the display area. The default is true.
        Returns:
        TRUE if the xy-limits are adjusted to match the aspect ratio of the display area, FALSE if are not adjusted to match the aspect ratio of the display area.

      • setPreserveAspect

        public void setPreserveAspect(boolean preserveAspect)
        Determine whether the xy-limits should be adjusted to match the aspect ratio of the display area. The default is true.
        Parameters:
        preserveAspect -

      • setLimits

        public void setLimits(double xmin,
                      double xmax,
                      double ymin,
                      double ymax,
                      double zmin,
                      double zmax)
        Set the limits of the view volume. The limits are set with respect to the viewing coordinates. That is, the view center is assumed to be at the point (0,0) in the plane of the screen. The view up vector (more precisely, its projection onto the screen) points upwards on the screen. The z-axis is perpendicular to the screen, with the positive direction of the z-axis pointing out of the screen. In this coordinate system, xmin and xmax give the horizontal limits on the screen, ymin and ymax give the vertical limits on the screen, and zmin and zmax give the limits of the view volume along the z-axis. (Note that this is NOT exactly the same as the parameters in either glOrtho or glFrustum! Most important to note is that zmin and zmax are given with reference to the view center, not the eye.) Note that xmin/xmax or ymin/ymax might be adjusted to match the aspect ratio of the display area.
        Parameters:
        xmin -
        xmax -
        ymin -
        ymax -
        zmin -
        zmax -

      • apply

        public void apply(com.jogamp.opengl.GL2 gl,
                  float[] position,
                  boolean setupLookAt)
        Apply the camera to an OpenGL context. This method completely replaces the projection and the modelview transformation in the context. It sets these transformations to the identity and then applies the view and projection represented by the camera. This method is meant to be called at the begining of the display method and should replace any other means of setting the projection and view.
        Parameters:
        gl -
        position -
        setupLookAt -

      • norm

        protected double norm(double[] v)

      • update

        public abstract void update(org.apache.commons.math3.geometry.euclidean.threed.Vector3D position,
                            org.apache.commons.math3.geometry.euclidean.threed.Vector3D rotation,
                            float dt)
        Set camera position and rotation, depending on the type of camera.
        Parameters:
        position - value of the controlled player position.
        rotation - value of the controlled player rotation.
        dt - the amount of elapsed game time since the last frame.
